At-a-Glance: A simple bloom calendar informs supering, splits, feeding, and marketing stories.
Why it Matters: Better timing yields better honey and calmer bees.
Creates content for labels and education.
Objectives: List key nectar/pollen sources by month.
Note timing shifts due to weather and microclimate.
Link to scale data and actions.
What Good Looks Like: Month-by-month table with local notes and photos.
Actions column: super, split, feed, move, market story.
Step-by-Step: 1) Draft calendar from experience and local guides.
2) Validate with weight logs and field notes.
3) Add photos and stories; publish to team.
4) Update post-season with real dates and outcomes.
Seasonality & Climate: Early springs advance trees; drought shortens herb blooms.
Data & Thresholds: Daily weight delta triggers in calendar.
Moisture targets and extraction windows noted.
Diagnostics & Decision Tree: Issue: Missed flow -> Check calendar lag; adjust next year; add alerts.
Issue: Dearth unknown -> Add gap species; shift splits earlier.
Issue: Marketing mismatch -> Align labels to bloom stories.
Common Pitfalls: Copying national calendars without local tweaks.
No photos or dates from own yards.
Tools & Techniques: Shared sheet, photos, QR codes to plant IDs.
Safety & Compliance: Do not publish precise hive locations without consent.
Notes: Keep separate columns for nectar vs pollen to plan nutrition.
